5.heading: Crane, Betsy.
5.title: Nurse Betsy Crane.
5.author: [No author]
notes: Published no. 12 (Aug. 1961) - no. 27 (Mar. 1964), cf. Overstreet comic book price guide.

6.heading: Crane, Brian.
6.title: "Actually, I Was Just Wiping My Nose"
6.author: by Brian Crane.
notes: Summary: Roscoe is nuzzling her leg, they think he likes her.

7.heading: Crane, Brian.
7.title: "Actually, I'm the One Who Ate the Wax Fruit"
7.author: by Brian Crane.
notes: Summary: Discussion about how Roscoe will eat anything, including crayons, TV remotes, car keys, pantyhose and wax fruit.

8.heading: Crane, Brian.
8.title: "Fetching the Remote"
8.author: by Brian Crane.
notes: Summary: It's suggested that Roscoe should fetch the remote, which Roscoe doesn't do.

9.heading: Crane, Brian.
9.title: "I Found Pieces of Two $100 Bills in His Mouth"
9.author: by Brian Crane.
notes: Summary: Even though dogs are inherently innocent and guiltless, Roscoe gets called a bad dog.

10.heading: Crane, Brian.
10.title: "Inside of a Dog, It's Too Dark To Read"
10.author: by Brian Crane.
notes: Summary: Nelson asks Grandpa why he reads so much, and he says that outside of a dog, reading is man's best friend. Roscoe sticks his head up in surprise at the punch line.

11.heading: Crane, Brian.
11.title: "Life Begins when the Kids Move Away and the Dog Dies"
11.author: B
notes: Summary: Earl startles Roscoe with his positive attitude toward aging (Roscoe is the dog).

12.heading: Crane, Brian.
12.title: Pickles : a Cartoon Collection
12.author: by Brian Crane ; foreword by Charles Schulz.
notes: Cover title: I Paints 'em as I Sees 'em.

13.heading: Crane, Brian.
13.title: "Probably About the Same as a Lamp Post Feels about Dogs"
13.author: B
notes: Summary: She's been finding fault with Dan a lot lately, and they wonder how that makes Dan feel.

14.heading: Crane, Brian.
14.title: "That's Not True, We Just Do It With Our Tails"
14.author: by Brian Crane.
notes: Summary: They're feeling sorry for Roscoe because dogs don't have the ability to laugh.

15.heading: Crane, Brian.
15.title: "That's the Trouble with Being a Dog: There are No Promotions"
15.author: Brian Crane.
notes: Summary: Roscoe laments that he'll never be a Golden Retriever.

16.heading: Crane, Brian--Articles About.
16.title: "Still Pickled After All These Years"
16.author: by Brian Crane
notes: Crane writes about his career, with a photograph of himself and samples and cast of characters of his strip Pickles.

27.title: "Isn't It Nice that Kids are Taking an Interest in the Classics Again?"
27.author: Detorie.
notes: Summary: On the street they hear teenagers insulting their acquaintances by calling them Holden Caulfield, Quasimodo, Ichabod Crane and Oedipus Rex types.

63.author: by Hal Higdon.
notes: An early version of an article scheduled for Air & Space Smithsonian (Oct./Nov. 1994).

135.heading: Crane, Walter S.
135.title: The Falcon and the Flame
135.author: written and illustrated by Walter S
notes: Most of this material was previously printed in Sheba, v. 2, issues 5-8.

"From the wilds of Persia to the pyramids of the Yucatan, Sheba's racking up the frequent flyer miles as Seth closes in on his target, a large striped box. But does the secret to thwarting this self-described 'ultimate evil' lie in the past, in the court of Egypt's final queen?"

136.heading: Crane, Walter S.
136.title: The Sands of Seth
136.author: written and illustrated by Walter S
notes: Most of the material was previously printed in the first seven issues of Sheba, 1996-1998.

"The tale of a dead cat. Sheba has been plastered in her tomb for centuries...her beloved Egypt has fallen into ruin under the spell of a trendy new religion...will the asinine ambitions of Seth trip up Sheba's plans for life after death after life?"

138.author: Victor de la Fuente
138.series: Haggarth : le Crâne aux Trois Serpents, chapt. 1
notes: "Au coeur d'une mystérieuse forêt, chevauche un groupe de sauvages guerriers Tunas. A leur tête, Haggarth, leur chef inflexible, que rien ne semble pouvoir détourner d'accomplir sa mission. Mais le passage de la troupe sauvage, prête à défier la vie et la mort, n'échappe pas à l'attention des paysans de cette région désolée. Leur union, la seule force qu'ils possèdent, mettra-t-elle en échec les projets sacrilèges d'Haggarth? Victor de la Fuente renoue ici avec l'atmosphère lourde et oppressante des aventures de Haxtur, qui l'avaient révélé, il y a quelques années au public français."

139.title: Le Crâne aux Trois Serpents ; chapt. 2 "Les Yeux de la Mort"
139.author: Victor de la Fuente
139.series: Haggarth : Le Crâne aux Trois Serpents, chapt. 2
notes: "A la tête de son groupe de sauvages tuerriers tunas, Haggarth s'est envoncé dans une région désolée. Son but: dérober, dans un monastère, le crâne aux trois serpents. Cette relique est le symbole de paix et d'unité des paysans qui peuplent cette contrée montagneuse. Sa disparition signifierait que chaque chef de clan se réclamerait du droit de gouverner les autres et que, defant un armée divisée, ce territoire deviendrait une proie facile pour les Tunas. Face au péril, les paysans se regroupent pour affronter les hommes d'Haggarth, ceux qui 'défient la vie et la mort'. La lutte s'engage, âpre et sauvage. Fauché par la hache d'un paysan, Haggarth s'effondre."

140.title: "Le Crâne de Cristal"
140.author: Sicomoro ; scénario de Serge Penard ; adaptation et mise en images de Claude Moliterni, d'après les personnages de Gaston Leroux
notes: "A la périphérie d'un Berlin en ruine, deux officiers de l'armée britannique prennent le thé avec un certain Ernest Schönerer venu les renseigner sur l'état de santé de la Roumanie."

141.title: "Le Crâne de Cristal"
141.author: Sicomoro ; scénario de Serge Pénard ; adaptation et mise en images de Claude Moliterni, d'après les personnages de Gaston Leroux
notes: "Le professeur Stangerson acceptera-t-il d'échanger sa fille contre le Crâne de cristal, qui représente pour lui vingt ans de recherche
Peut-être. A moins que Rouletabille n'intervienne à temps."

142.title: "Le Crâne de Cristal"
142.author: Sicomoro ; scénario de Serge Pénard, adaptation et mis en images de Claude Moliterni, d'après les personnages de Gaston Leroux
notes: "Rouletabille part seul délivrer la fille du professeur Stangerson. Entre lui et Mathilde Stangerson, l'étrange parfum d'une dame en noir flotte."

143.title: "Le Crâne de Cristal"
143.author: Sicomoro ; scénario de Serge Pénard ; adaptation et mise en images de Claude Moliterni, d'après les personnages de Gaston Leroux
notes: "Rouletabille vient de retrouver la fille du professeur Stangerson sur un bateau qui est, malheureusement, en train de couler."

144.title: Le Crâne de Cristal
144.author: Sicomoro ; scénario de Serge Pénard ; adaptation et mise en images de Claude Moliterni, d'après les personnages de Gaston Leroux ; mise en couleurs, Graziella Monti.

145.heading: Cranes.
145.title: Bill the Whooping Crane : and other wildlife picture stories
145.author: written and illustrated by Harry Baerg.
notes: Summary: Stories in comic book (panel and caption) format introduce the characteristics and habits of a variety of birds including the whooping crane, ostrich, eagle, owl, peacock, wild turkey, gull, and hummingbird.

148.title: "I Will Now Demonstrate Some of Our Basic Karate Moves"
148.author: Mike Peters.
notes: Summary: Moves named for birds: crane, eagle and chicken.

149.heading: Cranes.
149.title: "Nature's Critical Mass Overloads"
149.author: Mark Parisi.
notes: Summary: Whooping crane with whooping cough, skunk with cheap perfume, hyena on laughing gas, chihuahua drinking expresso.
